explanation:
For verifying MISRA "controlling expressions shall not be invariant" you must determine whether each conditional in OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew can be proven to be invariant (constant) at compile- or run-time or whether it can change during execution. The following symbols are required and why:

- OS_SharedGlobalVars
  - Needed to inspect the declaration/type/qualifiers of GlobalState (e.g. whether it is volatile/static/const) and to determine whether GlobalState can legitimately change at runtime (so that the expression comparing it is not an invariant).

- OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER
  - The constant against which GlobalState is compared. You need its definition/value to check if the comparison could be optimized to an invariant or accidentally equal to some other compile-time constant.

- OS_object_token_t
  - The function uses token and token->obj_id (passed to OS_NotifyEvent) and other token-manipulating callees. You must know the token layout and whether callees modify token fields used in subsequent control flow (so those expressions are not invariant).

- OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND, OS_ERR_NAME_TAKEN
  - The return_code comparisons test against these constants. Their definitions are needed to ensure they are distinct and to reason whether return_code tests can ever evaluate differently (i.e. are not tautologies).

- OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_ALLOCATED
  - Used when calling OS_NotifyEvent; need its value only to reason about side-effects or callbacks (if any) that might change global state used in later conditionals.

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit
  - Called before several return_code tests. You must inspect its prototype and side-effects to know if it can modify GlobalState, token, or any other storage that appears in later controlling expressions.

- OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch
  - Called when name != NULL. You need its semantics and side-effects (e.g. whether it can change token, global variables, or set persistent state) to determine if the subsequent tests (return_code comparisons) are invariant.

- OS_ObjectIdFindNextFree
  - Called as an alternative path when name is NULL or name not found. Its return value and side-effects can affect later conditionals; therefore its behavior must be known.

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel
  - Called when allocation fails; it may alter global state or token contents. Knowing whether it modifies variables that appear in later conditionals matters for invariance reasoning.

- OS_NotifyEvent
  - Called before OS_ObjectIdConvertToken and may invoke callbacks or change global state. If it can change GlobalState or other state tested later, the controlling expressions are not invariant.

- OS_ObjectIdConvertToken
  - Converts the token and calls other routines (per call graph). It may change token/global state and therefore affect later conditionals; its side-effects must be known.

- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew
  - Finalizer called when errors occur; it also calls OS_NotifyEvent per the graph. Its behavior and side-effects must be checked to see if they alter any variables used in controlling expressions.

In short: to determine whether any of the if(...) expressions in OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew are invariant you must know (a) whether the tested storage (GlobalState, token fields, return values) can be modified by other context or by the called functions, and (b) the exact values of the constants compared. The symbols above provide the declarations/definitions and the callees whose side-effects could affect invariance.
